fields.summary: ELB actions that do not support resource-level permissions fail to return error

comments.body: I think resource-level permission is not implemented for euca ELB (It was introduced June 2014).
[~sjones], please comment on what we can and cannot do. This behavior should be documented, [~hspencer]. Thank you!

[~sjones],

If you don't mind, could you put the information under [the section entitled 'AWS/Euca Federation Differences' on the 4.2 Federation wiki|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/QA/4.2+Federation#id-4.2Federation-AWS/EucaFederationDifferences]?  Thanks ahead of time.
[~hspencer], I'm not sure why this would be related to region federation.

[~sjones],

Thats where I was placing all ARN resource-level permission testing results I was doing.  Come to think of it, everything under the ['Eucalyptus Resource-Level and AWS Resource-Level Permissions'|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/QA/4.2+Federation#id-4.2Federation-EucalyptusResource-Levelvs.AWSResource-LevelPermissions] subsection can actually be on a separate page since it would apply on a single cloud (non-federated) as well.  Do you have a page where you were planning to document the ELB resource-level support?  If so, I will move that section to that page, and link to it.  Thoughts?
[~hspencer], I don't think there are any ELB specific resource-level permission changes in 4.2, in 4.1 there was EUCA-10052.

[~sjones],

Cool.  Looking at EUCA-10052, I am a bit confused.  Looking at the ticket, its stated to support ELB resource ARNs in 4.1.0 based upon the following documentation here:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/UsingIAM.html

So would it mean that EUCA-11229 is a bug then and should be fixed (or am I wrong in assuming the documentation hasn't changed for that section since the ticket EUCA-10052 was raised in Oct. 2014)?

EUCA-11229 is a difference in behaviour between us and AWS,  EUCA-10052 was about adding support for ELB ARNs and did not alter the (absent) failure behaviour seen when a resource was specified in the policy. We choose to behave differently from AWS in order to support more expressive policies allowing richer use of administrative roles. It should also be noted that AWS changes which actions allow resources to be specified as they add functionality, so there is moving target.
